docs.snippet: The annual general assembly of the International Press Institute approved resolutions today that condemn ''continued harassment and persecution'' of the press in South Africa and express concern about the press situation in some Latin American...
docs.lead_paragraph: The annual general assembly of the International Press Institute approved resolutions today that condemn ''continued harassment and persecution'' of the press in South Africa and express concern about the press situation in some Latin American countries. One resolution, passed by more than 300 delegates from about 40 countries, appealed to Prime Minister P.W. Botha of South Africa ''to accept press freedom as a prerequisite for a country that regards itself as part of the democratic world.'' The delegates, representing the press, broadcasting and other news outlets, said continued actions by the South African Government against freedom of thought and expression could lead only to further isolation of the country.

docs.snippet: When Chile was booming, some thought it a good advertisement for authoritarianism-cum-monetarism. The authoritarianism survives: troops swarmed through a Santiago shantytown in typical fashion last week and seized 1,000 alleged troublemakers. But...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Chile was booming, some thought it a good advertisement for authoritarianism-cum-monetarism. The authoritarianism survives: troops swarmed through a Santiago shantytown in typical fashion last week and seized 1,000 alleged troublemakers. But there is no more talk about economic miracles. The country is sinking, and a regime that took credit for a boom now tries to duck the blame for bust.

docs.snippet: Like many executives, William R. Rhodes likes to take a run around the reservoir in Central Park when time permits. But since last summer, Mr. Rhodes has not had much free time. And the word ''workout'' has taken on an entirely different meaning.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Like many executives, William R. Rhodes likes to take a run around the reservoir in Central Park when time permits. But since last summer, Mr. Rhodes has not had much free time. And the word ''workout'' has taken on an entirely different meaning. ''Last August I was on vacation in Quebec City when the phone rang early one morning,'' he recalls. ''It was the office, telling me the Mexicans were in trouble.''

docs.snippet: NACHA GUEVARA, the Argentine singer and actress whose solo show ''Nacha'' opened at the Top of the Gate last week, is hoping for a long run. ''A very long run,'' she said with a wistful smile the other day. ''I would like to stay in one place.''  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: NACHA GUEVARA, the Argentine singer and actress whose solo show ''Nacha'' opened at the Top of the Gate last week, is hoping for a long run. ''A very long run,'' she said with a wistful smile the other day. ''I would like to stay in one place.'' For the last nine years, since the day in 1974 when she was given 48 hours to get out of Argentina under a threat of death from a right-wing extremist organization, Miss Guevara and her husband, Alberto Favero, who is also her musical director and pianist, have been travelers - to Peru, to Mexico, to Venezuela, to Brazil, to Spain and now to the United States.

headline.main: OUSTED ARGENTINE SINGER WHO YEARNS TO SETTLE IN

docs.snippet: Uruguay's military rulers have broken off talks with civilian politicians and hinted that elections planned for next year might be delayed.   The suspension of the talks was announced by Gen. Julio Rapela, head of the Armed Forces Political Affairs...
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay's military rulers have broken off talks with civilian politicians and hinted that elections planned for next year might be delayed. The suspension of the talks was announced by Gen. Julio Rapela, head of the Armed Forces Political Affairs Committee, which represents the Government in the discussions.

headline.main: Around the World; Uruguayans Break Off Talks on Elections

docs.snippet: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, who ends a five-nation tour of Latin America Sunday, has used the occasion to criticize United States policy in the region.   Mr. Gonzalez visited five Spanish-speaking countries - the Dominican Republic,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, who ends a five-nation tour of Latin America Sunday, has used the occasion to criticize United States policy in the region. Mr. Gonzalez visited five Spanish-speaking countries - the Dominican Republic, Colombia, Venezuela, Panama and Mexico. The last four have undertaken a peace initiative in Central America that has been strongly supported by Spain. The Spanish leader began his criticism of United States policy in an interview with the Spanish news agency published the day before he left Spain, and he continued it in speeches and news conferences throughout the weeklong trip.

headline.main: SPANISH PREMIER ASSAILS U.S. OVER LATIN POLICIES

docs.snippet: Baseball Mets vs. Cubs at Chicago. Mike Torrez, who has a 2-6 record for the Mets but has not won since May 18, when he beat San Diego, 2-1, will be opposed by Steve Trout (4-6), who pitched for Chicago's other team last year. (Television - Channel...
docs.lead_paragraph: Baseball Mets vs. Cubs at Chicago. Mike Torrez, who has a 2-6 record for the Mets but has not won since May 18, when he beat San Diego, 2-1, will be opposed by Steve Trout (4-6), who pitched for Chicago's other team last year. (Television - Channel 9, 2 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 2:15 P.M.).
